Hi all,

I want to report our experience in unit testing using JUnit.
We're a project of 5 members building a GUI realtime app.

Our project package structure is:
<projectName>.<subject_x>.<element_y>.<sub-element_k>

When every project member has to write the piece of code he's been assigned
to he will first write the test unit of that piece in that way
he'll add a test class to such package structure:
<projectName_test>.<subject_xt>.element_y>.<sub_element_k>

When he's come to an end in the development of the unit tests for the whole
package he'll write a test suite to have all his test (for that package)
running.

In that way it's clear we're testing only public methods.
Why?
Because we're following a contract programming strategy: every memeber of
the team is in charge to build a specific part of the project; he's been
told (in a formal way) which are the responsibilities of his part and which
are the interfaces (the contracts) to be respected.
In that way, if I'm sure that my part does it job fine, every other part
will be able to successfully interact with my services.

Drawbacks:
One of the drawback that method seems to bring in is that the analysis part
of the project turns to be very critical and (unfortunately) not all project
leader (or boss) seems to be conscious of that.
At the project beginning, usually, neither the contractor nor the issuer,
seem to be aware of all the software requirements. Using a contract
programming strategy can be dangerous because some new requirements should
arise during the project development and anyone can imagine what could
happen to all interfaces if some interdependecies between the various entity
hasn't been taken into account or sone new ones arise.

Bye,
Luca Sfarzo

> I don't want to start another "holy war"...  just presenting another POV:
>
> if your production classes are located unter a src/ directory, just
> mirror your hierarchy in a test/ directory.
>
> you will have then: src/edu/washington/library/Book.java
> and your test in  : test/edu/washington/library/BookTest.java
>
> You will be able to test your public interface, striped them when
> dealing with the release but you will be able to:
> - test your protected methods
> - easily generate Javadoc with Ant (as far as I know, the Javadoc Ant
> task can't deal with FileSets, so it's impossible (?) to only include
> your production classes in your javadoc documentation)
>
> You can have a look at some really well organized projects (those of
> Jakarta for example - http://jakarta.apache.org) and see by yourself.
>
> But it's a matter of taste.
>
